page.title: 04NATIONAL TRUST TOPOGRAPHY
page.content: Blackdown is 280m. high and is the second tallest hill in S.E. England. The soil there is coarse sandstone with chert layers. The hard chert has prevented the hill from being worn away, but it was used by man for road surfaces so Blackdown is scarred with small quarries.Some sunken tracks have been formed through constant use as cart tracks and smugglers ways. The outline of Blackdown takes its shape from the clay layer underneath the sandstone. A spring line forms here, making the clay slippery and causing a landslip zone. Marley Common has basically the same formation as Blackdown but has become more eroded over the centuries and is scored by deep gullies.
